fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.bodyText: Super sickening Last year brought us three separate documentaries about women, including Louise Redknapp, attempting to starve themselves to a "size zero" in the name of investigative journalism. The incredible discovery in each case? Starving yourself isn't healthy, or fun. Shocking, I know. How to update this trend, though? Well, Channel 4 has decided that the next step is to combine fat and thin people in one fabulous package. Late January brings us Supersize v Superskinny, in which a 35-stone man follows the diet of a seven-and-a-half-stone woman, and vice versa, in the name of "therapy". Is it too much to hope that this is the last we see of diet porn on our TVs in 2008? It's making me feel nauseous. Bumped off Another thing I'd like to see the back of is the obsession with pregnant celebs. After weeks of speculation it's just been announced that Nicole Kidman is with child. Cue endless updates on her "condition". I have nothing against pregnancy or babies - I was one once myself - but why the fixation? Of course, some might suspect this is a not-so-subtle way of letting women know we're only interesting or worthwhile when we're making babies. But let's banish such cynical thoughts from our pretty little heads, eh folks? Sweet dreams If you're going to have a big wedding, you may as well go the whole hog, so hats off to Chidi Ogbuta of Texas. At her recent nuptials, Ogbuta fulfilled a long-held fantasy of having her wedding cake made as a life-size, surprisingly convincing replica, of ... her. Awesome! I like this lady's style, although it must have been creepy for her guests to see her new husband go at her with a knife ...
